comment_text:
The reactions from this fall along the lines of people who have service jobs who enjoy that WFH lifestyle, and the people who have jobs or lives that requrie them to work with city employees who are literally phoning it in.

Used to be a trip to city hall could resolve issues with permits, multiple agencies, or visiting the office of your rep to meet or at least make an appointment.

The building is just empty, and that shit doesn't work for a class of public sector employees who's main role is working for the public.

comment_text:
Let's just cut the bullshit Rivera. People have been doing their jobs from home for years now with no real issues with productivity. The cat is out of the bag, pandora's box is opened, etc. This isn't about the injustice of some people being able to work from home while some can't either.

You're trying to force a comeback for Downtown Seattle by making more people come back into town and I wouldn't be surprised if you were actively talking to business leaders in Seattle to make that happen. 

Instead of making Seattle a place people want to come to by making it a desirable place to be, you've decided to go down the route that requires the least amount of effort on your part and have decided to try to force Seattle upon everyone. 

It's the same antiquated leadership ideals you're seeing all across the Greater Seattle Area. Just stop trying to sell me a line on bullshit.

comment_text:
What the heck are you talking about?

Was at one of the big 3 around here when COVID hit, guess what? Nothing stopped. We all went home, logged in, and kept doing the job.

Products got released on time, contracts were signed on time, big deals were made on time. We had meetings every quarter where leadership got online and talked about how we were beating revenue, our KPI's, etc.

Now all the sudden once the situation has settled down, we need to "get back into the office" because "productivity is down" after multiple years of us kicking ass and experiencing huge stock gains all throughout the WFH era. Sounds like you already bought the bridge partner.

Because what it really is, is a bunch of Boomer bosses that don't like change, a bunch of middle managers that need to justify their existence, and a C-Suite that needs to justify the leases and ownership of these giant ass buildings. Meanwhile whenever I come in there's tons of inefficiencies. People have to commute and run into traffic and are late for meetings, sometimes their childcare falls through and they have to handle that and are stuck at home anyway, all the fucking bullshitting about Debbie's stupid kids and Craig's failing marriage in the hallway, the lunches that all the sudden turn from an hour in front of my home computer to hour and a half plus in the cafe because I'm with the team and the aforementioned bullshitting runs long... I could go on and on.

They also haven't even bothered hiring back half the staff that made coming in even worth it. No onsite IT, EA's are down, there's not enough seats/offices to go around because we've hired so much, the morale budget hasn't been brought back up to speed and we don't even get to have the traditional events, happy hours, gifts, etc. anymore.

I go in about twice a week when my manager and most of my team is in because I actually like my team and I am close to campus so I can't really bitch all that much. But if I had the commute some of my teammates do, you'd be lucky to see my ass more than once every other week. If I did show up too, I'd be out right after lunch to beat traffic and finish from home after I got my badge in for the day.

comment_text:
Return to work will have the opposite desired outcome like most city policies. Increasing the cost to work isn't going to increase the amount of discretionary income city workers have to spend downtown. Ironically this will cause people to bring coffee and food from home instead of treating themselves to something on their office days.

Ignoring the fact this push for 3 days a week is just to push some people out the door or into retirement. Anyone they can get to leave voluntarily right now reduces the number of layoffs they'll announce once the next budget is finalized. 

November is a weird ass time to try to revitalize downtown. People go out in the summer. November is however around the time 2025 budget will materialize.

comment_text:
This is not being done because the city government dislikes city employees, and even if they did, city employees have a lot of protections. It is being done because the political leaders in this city receive campaign contributions and kickbacks from property owners who own downtown buildings. They are trying to increase the usage of services, boost sales, and occupy buildings.

Some tasks can be carried out remotely as effectively as in person, while others benefit from team collaboration, interdepartmental teams, and providing mentorship for new employees. The commute to downtown is a concern, but long-term city employees should have already taken that into account when applying for and accepting their positions. Downtown is well-served by public transit, roads, bus connections, ferries, trains, etc. This does not mean commuting there is easy or pleasant, but it is better than other locations.

comment_text:
As a reminder city policies rarely yield the results envisioned by the egomaniacal leadership/politicians. Since the idiot mayor envisions this helping to "revitalize" downtown you can almost count on the opposite happening.

It's reasonable to assume what little discretionary income city workers have to spend downtown will not increase when you effectively issue a pay cut by increasing the cost to work. Another day in office increases commuting costs, childcare and pet care costs, cuts down on free time, etc.... City employees are not about to start going to happy hours and shopping after work because they're required to be their. They're about to start bringing their lunches and coffees from home.....
